patterns: where can i check voter registration status
responses: You can check their voter registation status at at the EC Election Headquarters, at the State Election Office Voter Register, review with MySPR Mobile app, with their SPR outreach units, or here at https://mysprsemak.spr.gov.my/semakan/daftarPemilih
The correction of any small information details is made at the State Election Office which will then be sent to the EC Headquarters for approval

patterns: Why is the spr in charge
which article law is the spr derive source of power
how many voter categories are there
responses: The voter category is divided into two: Ordinary voters and Absentee voters.

patterns: how do i register to vote
responses: From 15 December 2021, new voter registration will be automatic.

patterns: who are qualified to be voters
how do i qualify to vote
responses:
The qualifications to be registered as a new voter are: 
(a) Malaysian citizens 
(b) Aged 18 years and above 
(c) Resident in any electoral division (having a residential address registered with the National Registration Department) 
(d) Not disqualified based on Article 119 (3) of the Federal Constitution

The definition of disqualification to be registered as a voter based on Article 119 (3) of the Federal Constitution is: 
(a) on the date of eligibility, detained as a person of unsound mind or serving a sentence of imprisonment 
(b) before the qualifying date he has been convicted of an offense in any part of the Commonwealth and sentenced to death or imprisonment for a term exceeding twelve months and on that qualifying date he is still serving any sentence for that offence

patterns: How are winners decided in Malaysia
responses: The system used in Malaysia is based on the 'First-Past-The-Post-System'. This means that the candidates who obtain the majority will be declared the winners in the relevant electoral division
The important elements of the election are: Electoral Division, Selector, Candidates, Election Process

patterns: what are the types of elections
responses: There are two types of elections namely: General elections, Small Elections

patterns: why do we have general elections
responses: General Elections are held when the Parliament or State Legislative Assembly is dissolved or dissolves itself after the expiry of 5 years

By-Elections are held to fill vacancies in the Parliament or State Legislative Assembly due to unforeseen circumstances due to: Death, Resignation, Disqualified, or Annulment of election results by the Election Court

patterns: what is the process of elections
responses: General Elections or By-Elections in Malaysia involve six (6) stages which are the issuing of writs, nomination of candidates, election campaign, voting, official tallying of votes and announcement of election result

In the event of the dissolution of Parliament or the State Legislative Assembly or there is an unforeseen vacancy, the SPR will issue a writ that is a power of attorney to conduct elections to the Managing Officer. At the same time an election notice will be gazetted and posted in places that are easy for the public to check. The notice will contain the date of nomination and the date of voting to be conducted.

patterns: How can i become a candidate
responses: On the designated candidate nomination day, between 9.00 am and 10.00 am, the Managing Officer will receive nomination forms from candidates, proposers or supporters or all three at once. Apart from the submission of the nomination form, candidates, proposers or supporters must also include the election deposit and the Statutory Account Form which is Form 5 for candidates for members of the Dewan Rakyat and Form 5A for candidates for members of the State Assembly. These forms need to be stamped at the Stamp Duty Office. The Managing Officer will announce the candidates who are eligible to run after completing the nomination process. If only one candidate is eligible, the Managing Officer will announce that candidate won without contesting.
RM 10,000.00 for Parliamentary Elections and RM 5,000.00 for State Assembly Elections

patterns: how do you lose deposit money
responses: Candidates will lose their deposit money if they fail to obtain 1/8 of the total number of votes obtained by all the candidates contesting in a certain electoral division.

patterns: where do i pay the deposit
how do i pay the deposit
responses: Deposit money must be paid to the Managing Officer or State Election Director no later than 10.00 am on the day of nomination. Election Deposit can be paid in cash or bank draft.

patterns: what should i do during voting day
responses: Come early to the Voting Center and get the Voting Channel slip at the SPR Voter Register. If the polling station number is known, the voter can go directly to the voting station without going to the Voter Register and quietly queue at your voting channel. When it is your turn and you are allowed to enter the voting channel, please follow the voting procedure posted at the entrance of the channel, then leave immediately after voting.

patterns: where do i send coomplaints to
responses: Complaints regarding the election can be made at https://www.spr.gov.my/ms/aduan-pertanyaan.

patterns: who can apply for domestic postal voting
who are eligible for domestic postal voting
responses: Army officers, police officers, media, election officers, and officers of goverment agencies

patterns: how can i applty for postal voting
responses: Postal ballot applications by members and officers from this Agency must be done online at the MySPR portal via the following link: https://myspr.spr.gov.my/login

patterns: who can apply for overseas postal voting
who are eligible for overseas postal voting
responses: Malaysian citizens, students, and civil servantsa broads with their spouses

patterns: Privileges For A Candidate On Voting Day
responses: Candidates are allowed to visit the following places: Voting/counting place, Centralized and clustered vote counting centers, Center for the production, opening and counting of postal ballots, and Official Vote Tallying Center.
Contesting parties regsistered with the SPR can be viewed here: https://www.spr.gov.my/ms/pilihan-raya/penjalanan-pilihan-raya/calon
Eligible Malaysian citizens who have been registered as voters and whose names appear in the Electoral Register used in elections

patterns: What time do I need to be at the polling station?
responses: From 8.00 am to 6.00 pm in Semenjung Malaysia and 7.30 am to 5.30 pm in Sabah and Sarawak.
The required document is an Identity Card either My Kad or an old Identity Card either KPT or a Blue Plastic Identity Card.

No, However, in certain cases involving visually impaired voters, the voter must be accompanied by a person whom the voter trusts to help him to mark the ballot paper provided that person must first fill in Form 10.

patterns: How do I know more about the contesting candidates in my constituency before the election?
who are the candidates for voting
responses: You can find out more about the candidates through the media, the candidate's available social media pages (Twitter, TikTok or Facebook) and through the programs (talks or ceramah) that will be held in your area during the campaigning period

patterns: What is the difference between a Member of Parliament and a state assemblyman?
responses: Member of Parliaments go to the Dewan Rakyat as our representatives, and are involved in handling national issues and policy matters. While, Members of state assemblies have powers to enact state laws as provided for by the Constitution of Malaysia.

patterns: What is a constituency and how is it divided?
responses: A subdivision of a larger state created to provide its population with representation in the legislative body. Division is done through delineation, which is a process of dividing the Federal and State constituencies
A popular vote is the total votes received by a party or its coalition and

patterns: How many parliamentary seats are there?
responses: There are 222 parliamentary seats
There are 600 state legislative assembly seats in 13 states

patterns: How do I mark my ballot paper?
how do you sign ballot paper
responses: You can mark your ballot paper by crossing in the provided checkbox besides your chosen candidate

patterns: Will all the contesting parties be listed on the ballot paper?
responses: Yes. Furthermore, individual parties under a coalition may either use their own logo or their coalition's logo when contesting
Yes, your vote matters in determining your state and federal representative who in turn will decide on the policies that is best for the country and states
The majority vote is at least 112 votes of the House of Representatives and will form the federal government

patterns: Can I bring food/drinks when queuing at the polling station or go to the toilet while waiting for my turn to vote?
responses: You can bring snacks or water , and go to the toilet when queuing at the polling station

intents.tag: cast vote for more than one
patterns: Can I cast my vote for more than one candidate?
responses: You are required to vote for only ONE (1) candidate each for the Parliamentary seat and the state legislative assembly seat

patterns: Do I need to bring my own pen/pencil at the polling station?
responses: No, the pen to mark your ballot paper will be provided

patterns: Can I do an Instagram/Tiktok live while casting my vote?
Can i stream live while voting
responses: No, you are NOT allowed to take photos or videos when casting your vote

patterns: What happens if I leave the ballot paper empty?
responses: Empty ballot papers are not counted

patterns: If I am unable to go to the polling station or forget to vote, can I come on another date?
responses: No, you cannot come on another date to vote

patterns: Can I bring my parents/siblings to assist me at the polling station?
Can I bring other people to help me vote
Can i vote with a friend
responses: No, your friend or parent cannot accompany you when you are casting your vote. You can ask for help from EC officials if you need any help when casting your vote

The Election Commission does not fix a dress code for polling day, but it is advisable to dress appropriately or decently. However, voters must not wear clothes, carry an umbrella, water bottle or any other items that bear a party logo.

patterns: where can i check my polling place
responses: Polling station information is available at : the Election Commission website at https://mysprsemak.spr.gov.my/semakan/daftarPemilih; and the MySPR Semak mobile app

patterns: Why should i vote for a candidate
responses: Vote for your chosen candidate who represent your best interests
I'm sorry, I cannot answer that question to maintain neutrality

patterns: How old do i have to be to vote
how old is the voting age
responses: The voting age is 18 years old

patterns: Can i still vote if I have covid
responses: You are allowed to vote if you are Covid-19 positive and under home surveillance. However, the Election Commission will have a special arrangement for those involved.

patterns: What should i bring for to voting?
Do i need to bring anything to vote
responses: You need to bring the National Identification Card to the polling centre
No, it is not compulsary. However, it is a civic duty

patterns: Can i see the results of the election
responses: The results of the elction can be viewed here at: http://dashboard.spr.gov.my/
